key_insight: Combining spiking (event-driven) neural layers with a video transformer backbone yields a segmentation model that maintains high surgical scene accuracy while dramatically lowering compute and energy, enabling near real-time operation on constrained hardware.
problem_solved: Addresses the high computational cost and power consumption of state-of-the-art surgical segmentation models, which prevents reliable real-time deployment in resource-constrained operating-room systems and edge devices.
method: Introduce a spike-driven encoder that processes video frames event-style (sparse activations) to reduce redundant computation and power usage.
Integrate the spike encoder with a lightweight video transformer to capture temporal context and long-range dependencies across frames efficiently.
Design for hardware friendliness (sparse attention, low-precision/spike-compatible operations) to enable real-time potential on edge/neuromorphic platforms.
impact: Enables practical, low-latency surgical scene segmentation for intra-operative assistance and monitoring, making advanced perception models deployable on edge and power-limited systems. Useful blueprint for ML practitioners aiming to trade minimal accuracy loss for large energy and latency savings.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: spike-driven encoder feeding into a compact video transformer with annotations of sparse activations and data flow.
Bar chart: accuracy vs. latency/energy comparing standard transformer, CNN baselines, and the proposed spike-driven model.
Frame sequence visualization: original video frames + predicted segmentation masks over time to show temporal consistency and real-time frame rate.
Icon set: low-power chip, clock/latency symbol, and surgery/operating-room to emphasize deployment context and constraints.
paper_title: Surgical Scene Segmentation using a Spike-Driven Video Transformer with Real-Time Potential
paper_authors: Shihao Zou, Jingjing Li, Wei Ji, Jincai Huang, Kai Wang
